summary: Generates recalibration table for Base Quality Score Recalibration (BQSR)

arguments.summary: If true, adds a PG tag to created SAM/BAM/CRAM files.
arguments.name: --add-output-sam-program-record

arguments.summary: If true, adds a command line header line to created VCF files.
arguments.name: --add-output-vcf-command-line

arguments.summary: read one or more arguments files and add them to the command line
arguments.name: --arguments_file

arguments.summary: the binary tag covariate name if using it
arguments.name: --binary-tag-name
arguments.fulltext: The tag name for the binary tag covariate (if using it)

arguments.summary: BQSR BAQ gap open penalty (Phred Scaled).  Default value is 40.  30 is perhaps better for whole genome call sets
arguments.name: --bqsr-baq-gap-open-penalty

arguments.summary: Size of the cloud-only prefetch buffer (in MB; 0 to disable). Defaults to cloudPrefetchBuffer if unset.
arguments.name: --cloud-index-prefetch-buffer

arguments.summary: Size of the cloud-only prefetch buffer (in MB; 0 to disable).
arguments.name: --cloud-prefetch-buffer

arguments.summary: If true, create a BAM/CRAM index when writing a coordinate-sorted BAM/CRAM file.
arguments.name: --create-output-bam-index

arguments.summary: If true, create a MD5 digest for any BAM/SAM/CRAM file created
arguments.name: --create-output-bam-md5

arguments.summary: If true, create a VCF index when writing a coordinate-sorted VCF file.
arguments.name: --create-output-variant-index

arguments.summary: If true, create a a MD5 digest any VCF file created.
arguments.name: --create-output-variant-md5

arguments.summary: Assign a default base quality
arguments.name: --default-base-qualities
arguments.fulltext:
If reads are missing some or all base quality scores, this value will be used for all base quality scores.
 By default this is set to -1 to disable default base quality assignment.

arguments.summary: default quality for the base deletions covariate
arguments.name: --deletions-default-quality
arguments.fulltext: A default base qualities to use as a prior (reported quality) in the mismatch covariate model. This value will replace all base qualities in the read for this default value. Negative value turns it off. [default is on]

arguments.summary: If true, don't cache bam indexes, this will reduce memory requirements but may harm performance if many intervals are specified.  Caching is automatically disabled if there are no intervals specified.
arguments.name: --disable-bam-index-caching

arguments.summary: Read filters to be disabled before analysis
arguments.name: --disable-read-filter

arguments.summary: If specified, do not check the sequence dictionaries from our inputs for compatibility. Use at your own risk!
arguments.name: --disable-sequence-dictionary-validation

arguments.summary: Disable all tool default read filters (WARNING: many tools will not function correctly without their default read filters on)
arguments.name: --disable-tool-default-read-filters

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals to exclude from processing
arguments.name: --exclude-intervals
arguments.fulltext:
Use this argument to exclude certain parts of the genome from the analysis (like -L, but the opposite).
 This argument can be specified multiple times. You can use samtools-style intervals either explicitly on the
 command line (e.g. -XL 1 or -XL 1:100-200) or by loading in a file containing a list of intervals
 (e.g. -XL myFile.intervals).

arguments.summary: A configuration file to use with the GATK.
arguments.name: --gatk-config-file

arguments.summary: If the GCS bucket channel errors out, how many times it will attempt to re-initiate the connection
arguments.name: --gcs-max-retries

arguments.summary: Project to bill when accessing "requester pays" buckets. If unset, these buckets cannot be accessed.  User must have storage.buckets.get permission on the bucket being accessed.
arguments.name: --gcs-project-for-requester-pays

arguments.summary: display the help message
arguments.name: --help

arguments.summary: Size of the k-mer context to be used for base insertions and deletions
arguments.name: --indels-context-size
arguments.fulltext: The context covariate will use a context of this size to calculate its covariate value for base insertions and deletions. Must be between 1 and 13 (inclusive). Note that higher values will increase runtime and required java heap size.

arguments.summary: BAM/SAM/CRAM file containing reads
arguments.name: --input

arguments.summary: default quality for the base insertions covariate
arguments.name: --insertions-default-quality
arguments.fulltext: A default base qualities to use as a prior (reported quality) in the insertion covariate model. This parameter is used for all reads without insertion quality scores for each base. [default is on]

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are excluding.
arguments.name: --interval-exclusion-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -XL. For example, '-XL 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-XL 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Interval merging rule for abutting intervals
arguments.name: --interval-merging-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program merges abutting intervals (i.e. intervals that are directly side-by-side but do not
 actually overlap) into a single continuous interval. However you can change this behavior if you want them to be
 treated as separate intervals instead.

arguments.summary: Amount of padding (in bp) to add to each interval you are including.
arguments.name: --interval-padding
arguments.fulltext:
Use this to add padding to the intervals specified using -L. For example, '-L 1:100' with a
 padding value of 20 would turn into '-L 1:80-120'. This is typically used to add padding around targets when
 analyzing exomes.

arguments.summary: Set merging approach to use for combining interval inputs
arguments.name: --interval-set-rule
arguments.fulltext:
By default, the program will take the UNION of all intervals specified using -L and/or -XL. However, you can
 change this setting for -L, for example if you want to take the INTERSECTION of the sets instead. E.g. to
 perform the analysis only on chromosome 1 exomes, you could specify -L exomes.intervals -L 1 --interval-set-rule
 INTERSECTION. However, it is not possible to modify the merging approach for intervals passed using -XL (they will
 always be merged using UNION).

 Note that if you specify both -L and -XL, the -XL interval set will be subtracted from the -L interval set.

options.summary: Take the union of all intervals
options.name: UNION

options.summary: Take the intersection of intervals (the subset that overlaps all intervals specified)
options.name: INTERSECTION

arguments.summary: One or more genomic intervals over which to operate
arguments.name: --intervals

arguments.summary: One or more databases of known polymorphic sites used to exclude regions around known polymorphisms from analysis.
arguments.name: --known-sites
arguments.fulltext:
This algorithm treats every reference mismatch as an indication of error. However, real genetic variation is expected to mismatch the reference,
 so it is critical that a database of known polymorphic sites is given to the tool in order to skip over those sites. This tool accepts any number of
 Feature-containing files (VCF, BCF, BED, etc.) for use as this database. For users wishing to exclude an interval list of known variation simply
 use -XL my.interval.list to skip over processing those sites. Please note however that the statistics reported by the tool will not accurately
 reflected those sites skipped by the -XL argument.

arguments.summary: Lenient processing of VCF files
arguments.name: --lenient

arguments.summary: minimum quality for the bases in the tail of the reads to be considered
arguments.name: --low-quality-tail
arguments.fulltext: Reads with low quality bases on either tail (beginning or end) will not be considered in the context. This parameter defines the quality below which (inclusive) a tail is considered low quality

arguments.summary: If non-zero, partitions VCF output into shards, each containing up to the given number of records.
arguments.name: --max-variants-per-shard

arguments.summary: The maximum cycle value permitted for the Cycle covariate
arguments.name: --maximum-cycle-value
arguments.fulltext:
The cycle covariate will generate an error if it encounters a cycle greater than this value.
 This argument is ignored if the Cycle covariate is not used.

arguments.summary: Size of the k-mer context to be used for base mismatches
arguments.name: --mismatches-context-size
arguments.fulltext: The context covariate will use a context of this size to calculate its covariate value for base mismatches. Must be between 1 and 13 (inclusive). Note that higher values will increase runtime and required java heap size.

arguments.summary: default quality for the base mismatches covariate
arguments.name: --mismatches-default-quality
arguments.fulltext: A default base qualities to use as a prior (reported quality) in the mismatch covariate model. This value will replace all base qualities in the read for this default value. Negative value turns it off. [default is off]

arguments.summary: The output recalibration table file to create
arguments.name: --output
arguments.fulltext:
After the header, data records occur one per line until the end of the file. The first several items on a line are the
 values of the individual covariates and will change depending on which covariates were specified at runtime. The last
 three items are the data- that is, number of observations for this combination of covariates, number of reference mismatches,
 and the raw empirical quality score calculated by phred-scaling the mismatch rate.   Use '/dev/stdout' to print to standard out.

arguments.summary: Don't recalibrate bases with quality scores less than this threshold (with -bqsr)
arguments.name: --preserve-qscores-less-than
arguments.fulltext:
This flag tells GATK not to modify quality scores less than this value. Instead they will be written out unmodified in the recalibrated BAM file.
 In general it's unsafe to change qualities scores below < 6, since base callers use these values to indicate random or bad bases.
 For example, Illumina writes Q2 bases when the machine has really gone wrong. This would be fine in and of itself,
 but when you select a subset of these reads based on their ability to align to the reference and their dinucleotide effect,
 your Q2 bin can be elevated to Q8 or Q10, leading to issues downstream.

arguments.summary: number of distinct quality scores in the quantized output
arguments.name: --quantizing-levels
arguments.fulltext:
BQSR generates a quantization table for quick quantization later by subsequent tools. BQSR does not quantize the base qualities, this is done by the engine with the -qq or -bqsr options.
 This parameter tells BQSR the number of levels of quantization to use to build the quantization table.

arguments.summary: Whether to suppress job-summary info on System.err.
arguments.name: --QUIET

arguments.summary: Read filters to be applied before analysis
arguments.name: --read-filter

arguments.summary: Indices to use for the read inputs. If specified, an index must be provided for every read input and in the same order as the read inputs. If this argument is not specified, the path to the index for each input will be inferred automatically.
arguments.name: --read-index

arguments.summary: Validation stringency for all SAM/BAM/CRAM/SRA files read by this program.  The default stringency value SILENT can improve performance when processing a BAM file in which variable-length data (read, qualities, tags) do not otherwise need to be decoded.
arguments.name: --read-validation-stringency

arguments.summary: Reference sequence file
arguments.name: --reference

arguments.summary: Output traversal statistics every time this many seconds elapse
arguments.name: --seconds-between-progress-updates

arguments.summary: Use the given sequence dictionary as the master/canonical sequence dictionary.  Must be a .dict file.
arguments.name: --sequence-dictionary

arguments.summary: display hidden arguments
arguments.name: --showHidden

arguments.summary: If true, don't emit genotype fields when writing vcf file output.
arguments.name: --sites-only-vcf-output

arguments.summary: Temp directory to use.
arguments.name: --tmp-dir

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkDeflater (as opposed to IntelDeflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-deflater

arguments.summary: Whether to use the JdkInflater (as opposed to IntelInflater)
arguments.name: --use-jdk-inflater

arguments.summary: Use the base quality scores from the OQ tag
arguments.name: --use-original-qualities
arguments.fulltext:
This flag tells GATK to use the original base qualities (that were in the data before BQSR/recalibration) which
 are stored in the OQ tag, if they are present, rather than use the post-recalibration quality scores. If no OQ
 tag is present for a read, the standard qual score will be used.

arguments.summary: Control verbosity of logging.
arguments.name: --verbosity

arguments.summary: display the version number for this tool
arguments.name: --version

description:
First pass of the base quality score recalibration. Generates a recalibration table based on various covariates. The default covariates are read group, reported quality score, machine cycle, and nucleotide context.

This walker generates tables based on specified covariates. It does a by-locus traversal operating only at sites that are in the known sites VCF. ExAc, gnomAD, or dbSNP resources can be used as known sites of variation. We assume that all reference mismatches we see are therefore errors and indicative of poor base quality. Since there is a large amount of data one can then calculate an empirical probability of error given the particular covariates seen at this site, where p(error) = num mismatches / num observations. The output file is a table (of the several covariate values, num observations, num mismatches, empirical quality score).

Input

The input read data whose base quality scores need to be assessed.

A database of known polymorphic sites to skip over.

Output

A GATK Report file with many tables:

  1. The list of arguments
  2. The quantized qualities table
  3. The recalibration table by read group
  4. The recalibration table by quality score
  5. The recalibration table for all the optional covariates
The GATK Report is intended to be easy to read by humans or computers. Check out the documentation of the GATKReport to learn how to manipulate this table.

Examples

 gatk BaseRecalibrator \
   -I my_reads.bam \
   -R reference.fasta \
   --known-sites sites_of_variation.vcf \
   --known-sites another/optional/setOfSitesToMask.vcf \
   -O recal_data.table
name: BaseRecalibrator
